This challenge is about RSA key generation and computing the different components.

For starters, 2 secret distinct (large)  prime numbers *p* and *q* are chosen and *pq = n* is calculated.
For the public key component we use *n* together with a number *e* which is larger than 1 and smaller than
(and co-prime to) the *totient(n)*. This is Eulers totient function which counts the number of relatively
prime integers to a given integer *n* which is less than *n*.

So to encrypt a message *m* we take the message to the power of *e* modulus *n*.
To decrypt the ciphertext we need to calculate the private key component *d* which is the modular multiplicative 
inverse of. Which means *e* times *d* modulus *n* is congruent to 1. We then use *d* for decryption in the same
manner as encryption. Ciphertext *c* to the power of *d* modulus *n*.

The questions in this quiz is pretty straightforward. We are prompted with some of the components and then asked
if it is possible for us to calculate another component. The questions are also the same every time. For the 
fun of it I will try to write a Python program which will calculate all this for me. ATM, I just have the
issue of calculating *d* properly to solve the challenge. Below follows the answers to the pop-quiz.

Note:
The reason that the third question is unfeasible to calculate is because that requires prime factorization of
the component *n* to find the correct *p* and *q*. This is not impossible, but extremely hard and also the 
source of the security level of the algorithm.

#Answer inputs#
Y
4636878989
Y
93089
N
Y
836623060
Y
